pullRequest.body:
Includes an auto-fix feature with the `--fix` flag so that spacing suggestions will be automatically applied in review also.

---
- [x] depends on : #7328 

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: should be rebased once #7286 is merged
after adding `protected`, we should wait for #7296 and then rebase...
@alexjbest I'm trying to get this to work with reviewdog, but the "lint and suggest" workflow is skipped. Is there a way to make sure it will not be skipped?
waiting also for #7321

> @alexjbest I'm trying to get this to work with reviewdog, but the "lint and suggest" workflow is skipped. Is there a way to make sure it will not be skipped?

I recently changed it to skip draft prs, is that the reason it is skipping? In which case I'm sure it's fine to make your pr not a draft and mark it WIP instead

> > @alexjbest I'm trying to get this to work with reviewdog, but the "lint and suggest" workflow is skipped. Is there a way to make sure it will not be skipped?
> 
> I recently changed it to skip draft prs, is that the reason it is skipping? In which case I'm sure it's fine to make your pr not a draft and mark it WIP instead

Cool, now it is at least running. But it doesn't manage to make suggestions. `./scripts/lint_style.sh --fix` works fine locally and makes these changes, but they don't get picked up by the reviewdog...
That's possibly as reviewdog only makes suggestions on lines changed in your pr? I don't see any lean files changed in this pr so in that case it won't suggest anything
That makes perfect sense! Then everything works as intended here...
lint should pass after #7328 is merged
During the time it took for the review of #7328, a few new cases where this new linter triggered where added to mathlib. I added fixed for them here.

LGTM I think this will on average reduce the number of spacing comments people have to leave on PRs, so I'm in favour

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alexjbest.

LGTM

bors merge
bors d+
(if new conflicts have arisen)

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6353613135/job/17258619194)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6353613135/job/17258619425)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6353613135/job/17258619671)
If anyone is interested I just saw this linter in action https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7442, looks like it is working well!

```suggestion
            output_message(path, line_nr, "ERR_2SP", "If the theorem statement requires multiple lines, indent the subsequent lines by 4 spaces")
```
This misses `protected theorem`
trying to account for that now

```suggestion
            output_message(path, line_nr, "ERR_4SP", "If the theorem statement requires multiple lines, indent the subsequent lines by 4 spaces")
```

```suggestion
ERR_4SP = 17 # second line not indented
```
This will only work for statements where the keyword (such as `lemma`) is on the same line as the `:`. Would it make sense to try to generalize this?

Good idea. I have added that. That only has the slight problem that if we have a doc string like this
```
blba bla
lemma blabla 
bla bla
```
it will get triggered. I'm not sure if this can be avoided without keeping track if we are currently in a doc string by parsing `/--` and `-/`

We already have some logic in the style linters for annotating comment lines with `annotate_comments` this sticks a `True` on the end if we are in a comment (or if there is a comment at the end of the line iirc). So like some of the others I think it would be fairly easy to skip linting those lines
ah good, I hadn't seen that and now added parsing if we are in comments..., but I will convert it to use `annotate_comments`...

Funnily there are some examples of source code inside comments where linting would be a good idea, like one could consider stuff inside ` ``` ...``` ` as code again. But perhaps this is more easily done manually
Oh definitely! There are even `begin ... end` blocks inside comments still. But yeah it does seem more complexity than its worth at this point
ok, I think this works now: Additional fixes from that here: #7328

```suggestion
  -- Porting note: proofs were `tidy` or `simp`
```
Should this match `instance` too?
Sure, why not. I'm happy to add it either in this pull request or in a separate one....
Let's add it in this one

I think the negations are easier to parse as
```suggestion
            if not (next_line == '\n' or next_line.startswith("#") or stripped_next_line.startswith("--")):
```
This also presumably won't match `@[simp] lemma`?

Indeed, but we could be here all day trying to reproduce the grammar of lean declarations in python.
Like `irreducible_def`, `private`, `noncomputable`, etc. etc.
I don't think there is anything wrong with adding attributes here too, but after a point we really need to either do these things in lean itself (I assume once someone makes one such linter making the rest will be easy), or use something like tree-sitter at least so we aren't reimplementing this all the time.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - style: a linter for four spaces

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: only four spaces for subsequent lines
